Any tips for staying positive in face of confusion and thoughts like what the fuck maybe i\'m not cut out for this lol learn python  it's easy and confidenceboosting I wouldn't say it's easy. It is not _always_ easy but it is fairly straightforward compared to other languages Uh There are two easy ways to fight against that feeling 1) Get a support group that gives you positive reinforcement no matter what.2) Figure out what progress looks like and how fast you are making progress. Make sure you are completing modules in the same amount of time as other people ect ect. It\'s generally a good idea to ask "How would I tell if someone else isn\'t cut out for x? You develop some metrics find flaws in your metrics fix them then you apply them to yourself and see how you stack up Getting through a chapter a week is pretty good Set small goals. Even though they might be very simplistic resolving them helps relieve that feeling of not making any progress. Goal setting will give you a positive feelings too. I mean people learn different things at different rates too. Cut out for has to have some pass fail criteria Not getting through the same number of chapters as another person as quickly doesn't have to mean that you're not cut out to be a programmer. I suggest addressing this feeling which stems from uncertainty / bad measurements of self worth It actually might IMHO If you are in the bottom 10% of programmers or move 80% slower That might work if it turns out that you are in fact measuring up to other people and you're just mistaken about it. You are fighting a huge uphill battle given programming is sorta competitive anyway I'm not sure what you mean by that. I don't find programming to be competitive at all. Uhhh It's more like it's innately collaborative. I compete with other people for good jobs higher status whatever The job market here is so good that I don't have to compete. There are jobs for people who are way less experienced and talented than me. I think the idea of not being cut out for something is kind of a misconception in itself. Success is probably at least 90% hard work in any case. ....UH that's ..not right If you're frustrated there's bound to be ways you can improve your learning methodology. I mean maybe there are jobs for really crap programmers. But I think there is a space for telling people to packup and go home and do something they would be better at. Of course whoever you are giving advice to can overcome their challenges and succeed I think it's exceedingly unlikely that advice is going to be constructive. But really the argument to pack it up and pack it in applies to best use of time to some metric There's no way you can have enough for information to make that judgment. I think it's very likely the advice is going to be constructive Over discord? Probably not And you can very easily destroy what little confidence someone has by saying something like that. That's not really an objection It's actually a bit of a conjecture . I would be invigorated if someone told me I couldn't do something That's what I mean by it not being constructive. You can't know that it's true and if you use it you're much more likely to harm than help. You are the exception then. That's also conjecture and pretty limited You can give constructive negative feedback just as well as positive feedback Ok let me rephrase. Sure Maybe you're not the exception but you belong to a specific class of people. There's a significant number of other people who do not respond well to being told they are innately unfit for something. It's careless to assume that other people are going to be like you in this regard. What does it mean when something is Lazy? @Hotfix As in lazy evaluation"? It is generated when you need it @Hotfix not respond well carries a lot of baggage / is doing a lot of heavy lifting in your statement @Sinthrill I can elaborate on it but if you'll interpret me charitably I'm sure you can imagine what I mean by it. You're talking about lazy generators introduced in py3 I guess? well in some ways you are right and other ways you are wrong. Ok can we talk some python? :pithink: Agreed. Not being in that class of people you can understand that I wouldn't be naturally predisposed to that pov so I have to make guesses. sure Let's move this to ot if you want to continue offtopic ? ot0 ? Sure So what I was wondering  is there a way to run a shell command without subprocess? Probably but why you don't want to use subprocess? @nekitdev you can use os.system i think popen might be a thing in os as well There is `os.popen` too well as silly as it is I donï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t have multiprocessing :pensive_snake_cowboy: alright Iï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ll see You don't want to return until the command is terminated? subprocess is the recommended approach though. `os.popen` is deprecated But `os.system` is not `system()` just call the C function `system() ` ```py proc = subprocess.Popen( ... # command here stderr=subprocess.STDOUT stdin=subprocess.PIPE, stdout=subprocess.PIPE cwd=cwd env=env, )``` I am trying to get the same thing as this but without using subprocess :pithink: I don't think you can :roothink: ï¿½ï¿½\\_(ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½)_/ï¿½ï¿½ Maybe you can use `popen` but it is deprecated just checked canï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t do that as well haha You can use `os.system` and redirect the output to a file

Is it good to use the same function in a function to loop it? Like to ask a player if they wanna play again. loops are generally better in this case certainly But it does sound like for what you're doing loops will be much better you generally want to avoid recursion in python it does not handle as well as it could Is it likely that Python ever gets better at recursion? Or is it just sort of stuck like this because of the way the language is? I feel like at least tail recursion could be done what complaints do you have? First of all the limit of 1000 is annoying ```python idk = lambda x :[x.append(list(i[1]).sort()) for i in x]print(idk([(0,2),(4,3),(9,9),(10,1)]))``` i want to get the output as 1,2,3,9 you can change that second of all tail recursion is pretty nice but it throws me error .sort() returns None as does .append() and i[1] will be an int I've found most anything I could do with tail recursion I could do more efficiently with a stack (read: a list) This really seems like it belongs in #esotericpython then how to get the ouput without using map function why are you doing this in the first place? @Infinimata having to manage a stack yourself is often just less readable than tail recursion `sorted(j for i,j in x)` Yeah but it means that many less function calls that many less stack frames created and destroyed which are really expensive operations and managing the stack amounts to what pushing and popping elements into and from a list? ye there are ways around tail recursion```pydef tailrec(a b=0 c=0): while True: if cond: a,b,c = a  1 ~b c else: return a + b```this is a neat way Yeah. I'm not saying its terrible at the moment just it'd be nice if Python was happier with tail recursion. If it could optimise more of the overhead away I do doubt it can do C level of recursion optimalization though I don't understand either Python or tail recursion enough for too much detail in this discussion tho I think there's a discussion GvR had at one point about why it's not a good fit What is `~b`? also GvR? Guido van Rossum Python's creator oh guido yeah I misread it. Thought GvR was a book or something binary inverse `__invert__` i1 on ints no real meaning here there were a few reasons he gave but one was that it obfuscates stack traces another is that if it's tail recursive you can do it with normal iteration huh just realized davidism hangs out in here. small world depends on who you ask. > Hello how do you compare 2 strings together and print the amount of similar values?@juls ```py# Time space complexity will be: # O(1) Space | O(n) Timedef countSimilarChar (string1 string2): # this variable will keep track of  # of the number of time it sees characters # that are similar  NumberOfSimilarities = 0 # this part of the algorithm is to find the longer # string of the two in order to use that lengh in # the for loop to make sure we check every characters  # in the string longer = lambda a,b: a if len(a) > len(b) else b shorter = lambda a,b: a if len(a) < len(b) else b # Using the above formula  longerString = longer(string1 string2) shorterString = shorter(string1 string2) # this is where it start iterating to count  # character similarities  for each in longerString: if each in shorterString: NumberOfSimilarities += 1 return NumberOfSimilarities``` > Hello i just started to learn python@James M. hi me too What does that have to do with Python https://pypi.org/project/robotspy/ this may come in handy for robots.txt wat robots.txt? Both `and` and `or` may skip the second check depending on the result of the first. `or` skips if the first statement evaluates to `True` whereas `and` skips if the first statement evaluates to `False` yup this is termed shortcircuit evaluation it's neat but I think it makes code harder to understand so I avoid it I agree @gm but it is a good guide for perspective if you prefer to write in a more functional style (I do) then using stuff like `and` and `or` as operators is more common but it is also true that some people find that a lot less readable which is reasonable Anyone else able to give their thoughts? https://discordapp.com/channels/267624335836053506/291284109232308226/662842497499922442 is there anyway while in a loop to say immeidiatly start the next loop kinda like break but only for that one loop? Yeah that does make sense actually. I guess it's just drawing a conclusion based on the result of the first and then immediately using that conclusion in the same line violates the zen of python. My take is that you express one idea or sentence per line of code though depending on the complexity of the idea you might be able to sneak in a little more. I am it's soon to expire sadly Is there a way that I can start a background task with asyncio in Python like threading? @Djdude02 The point of classes is to let you create multiple objects of a single type and have each of those objects hold it's own independent state. Classes also allow encapsulating that state to allow invariants to be enforced like that a particular attribute is always positive or something like that List is a class. Your program is able to create multiple lists. Those lists don't share data. The lists expose methods to manipulate their state by adding or removing elements or sorting the elements. Makes more sense Classes are just user defined types composed of state that is made up of existing Python types and exposing methods allowing users to read or change that state. That's it. I think iï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ve seen stack overflows but not heap hm None As for the heap that is managed by a garbage collector. You can allocate lots of objects and eventually run out of heap space and Python will raise a MemoryError but it\'s going to take a fair amount of time. You actually did that with your \'stack overflow\ example in the question. You stored a reference to a string on the stack this string took up all the free memory available to the process. You're welcome > Cython does some neat optimizations that can make things just a tad bit fasterCythonizing something like this makes pretty minimal optimizations since it's still calling to the Python C API```pythondef py_loop(): x = 0 for i in range(50): x += i``` But then if you optimize it suddenly you're actually using a C loop```pythondef cy_loop(): cdef int x = 0 cdef int i for i in range(50): x += i``` For Game Jam are you allowed to use standard libraries?
